sen.j: 大伴御行（おおとも の みゆき、大化2年（646年）? - 大宝 (日本)元年1月15日 (旧暦)（701年2月27日））は、日本の飛鳥時代の人物である。
sen.e: OTOMO no Miyuki (646? – February 27, 701) was active in the Asuka period of Japan.
OTOMO no Miyuki (646? – March 3, 701) was a figure in the Asuka period of Japan.

sen.e: OTOMO no Miyuki (646? – March 3, 701) was a figure in the Asuka period of Japan.

sen.j: 旧仮名遣いでの読みは「おほとものみゆき」。
sen.e: In old Japanese syllabary characters, his name had been written as Ohotomo no Miyuki, and it is considered to have been pronounced as Ofotomo no Miyuki.
sen.cmt: 飛鳥時代に、は行はFで発音されていたのでOfotomoとなります。
sen.e: In old Japanese orthography, his name had been written as Ohotomo no Miyuki, and it is considered to have been pronounced as Ofotomo no Miyuki.
sen.cmt: 「旧仮名遣い」をデータベースに合わせ、old Japanese orthographyとしました。

sen.j: 姓（カバネ）は連、後に宿禰。
sen.e: His kabane (hereditary title) was Muraji; later he was given a new kabane, Sukune (third highest of the eight hereditary titles).
sen.cmt: 連はthe eight hereditary titles施行前に与えられていた姓だと考えられるので、括弧に階級を補いません。

sen.e: In the Jinshin War of 672, he played an important role supporting Oama no Miko (Oshiama no Miko or Prince Oama, who became Emperor Tenmu following the victory in the war).

sen.e: In the period of Empress Jito and of Emperor Monmu, he served as Dainagon (chief councilor of state) at a high rank.

sen.j: 贈正広弐、贈右大臣。

sen.j: 大伴氏は飛鳥時代の有力氏族である。
sen.e: The Otomo clan was a powerful clan in the Asuka period.
The Otomo clan was a powerful clan in the Asuka period.

sen.j: 御行の父は大伴長徳で孝徳天皇の大臣、叔父に大伴馬来田、大伴吹負がおり、弟に大伴安麻呂がいる。
sen.e: Miyuki's father was OTOMO no Nagatoko who served Emperor Kotoku as a minister; OTOMO no Maguta and OTOMO no Fukei were Miyuki's uncles; OTOMO no Yasumaro was his younger brother.

sen.j: 『竹取物語』に登場する「大納言大伴のみゆき」はこの御行をモデルにしているとされる。
sen.e: Dainagon Otomo no Miyuki' which was one of characters of "Taketori Monogatari" (The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter) is considered to have been modeled on this actual OTOMO no Miyuki.

sen.j: この乱では大伴馬来田が大海人皇子に従っておそらく美濃まで行き、吹負が倭（大和）方面の軍の指揮をとる将軍になった。
sen.e: In the war, Miyuki's uncles played very important roles; OTOMO no Maguta is considered to have accompanied Oama no Miko to Mino Province, and Maguta's younger brother Fukei became a general and led the army mainly in Yamato Province.
In this war, OTOMO no Maguta is considered to have accompanied Oama no Miko probably to Mino Province, and Fukei became a general and led the army mainly in Yamato Province.

sen.j: また、御行の弟の安麻呂の名が吹負挙兵直後の連絡の使者のうちに見える。
sen.e: Immediately after Fukei raise his army, Miyuki's younger brother Yasumaro delivered Fukei's important message to Oama no Miko.
Immediately after Fukei raise his army, Miyuki's younger brother Yasumaro was one of messengers delivering Fukei's important message to Oama no Miko.

sen.j: 御行も同族の一員として一部隊の指揮官になったのだろう。
sen.e: Therefore, Miyuki is considered to have become a commander of a troop as a member of the same clan as Fukei.

sen.j: 戦後、大伴連御行が功績により100戸の封戸を与えられたことが、『続日本紀』大宝元年（701年）7月21日条により知られる。
sen.e: According to the article of July 21, 701 of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), OTOMO no Muraji Miyuki was given a salary of 100 fuko (equal to 100 taxed families) for his achievement in the war.

According to the article about July 21of the first year of the Taiho era (September 2, 701) of "Shoku Nihongi" (Chronicle of Japan Continued), OTOMO no Muraji Miyuki was given a salary of 100 fuko (equal to 100 taxed families) for his achievement in the war.
sen.cmt: この「大宝元年（701年）7月21日」は書物に記載されている内容のため、和暦を使用し、カッコ内にグレゴリオ暦を補足しました。

sen.j: 『万葉集』で御行が「大将軍」と記されるのも、この乱で顕著な功績を立てたためではないかと推測する向きもある。
sen.e: In the oldest anthology of Japanese poetry, "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves), Miyuki's name was written with the title 'Daishogun' (the great general), based on that, some scholar says that Miyuki had accomplished an outstanding achievement in the war.
sen.cmt: 『万葉集』には短歌以外の形式の歌も載っていますので、tankaを避けます。
sen.e: Some people tend to presume that the reason why Miyuki's name was written with the title 'Daishogun' (the great general) in the oldest anthology of Japanese poetry, "Manyoshu" (Collection of Ten Thousand Leaves), is that Miyuki had accomplished an outstanding achievement in the war.
sen.cmt: 原文にはないsome scholarを削除し、「推測する向きもある」を訳出して全体を変更しました。

sen.j: だが、御行の戦功はそれほどでもなく、彼に対する賞は吹負ら大伴氏全体の功に対する部分が大きいと見る説もある。
sen.e: However, some scholar says that Miyuki was given the title not for his own achievement but for the whole achievements the Otomo clan such as Fukei had produced.

sen.e: On March 16, 675 (in old lunar calendar), when his rank was Shokinjo (fifth rank), OTOMO no Muraji Miyuki was appointed to Tsuwamono no Tsukasa no Taifu (subordinate officer of the department of military affairs).
On April 19, 675, when his rank was Shokinjo (fifth rank), OTOMO no Muraji Miyuki was appointed to Tsuwamono no Tsukasa no Taifu (subordinate officer of the department of military affairs).

sen.e: On December 2, 684 (in old lunar calendar), OTOMO no Muraji Miyuki was given a new kabane (hereditary title), Sukune (third highest of the eight hereditary titles).
On January 15, 685, OTOMO no Muraji was given a new kabane (hereditary title), Sukune (third highest of the eight hereditary titles).

sen.j: 天武天皇14年（685年）9月18日に、天武天皇は皇族・臣下と大安殿で博打をして遊んだ。
sen.e: On September 18, 685 (in old lunar calendar), Emperor Tenmu invited the imperial family and vassals to Oan-dono (Oan Hall), and was amused with games and gambles.
On October 24, 685, Emperor Tenmu invited the imperial family and vassals to Oan-dono (Oan Hall), and was amused with games and gambles.

sen.j: このとき天皇は大安殿の中に、皇族と臣下は殿の前に位置した。
sen.e: At this time, although Emperor Tenmu sat inside Oan-dono, the imperial family and vassals sat outside Oan-dono to play games.

sen.j: 大伴宿禰御行はこの日に天皇の衣と袴を与えられた10人のうちにあった。
sen.e: According to a record, on the same day, the Emperor gave ten vassals his jackets and hakama (Japanese loose-fitting trousers), and OTOMO no Sukune Miyuki was one of them.
On this day, the Emperor gave ten vassals his robe and hakama (pleated and divided skirt for men), and OTOMO no Sukune Miyuki was one of them.

sen.j: 持統天皇2年（688年）11月11日、前年に死んだ天武天皇が大内陵に葬られたとき、大伴宿禰御行は布勢御主人（阿倍御主人）とともに誄した。
sen.e: On November 11, 688 (in old lunar calendar), Emperor Tenmu who had died in 687 was buried in Ochi-no-misasagi Tomb, OTOMO no Sukune Miyuki and FUSE no Minushi (AHE no Minushi) praised the Emperor's achievements.
sen.cmt: 大内陵Ochi-no-misasagi Tomb布勢御主人（阿倍御主人）FUSE no Minushi (AHE no Minushi)…岩波文庫『日本書紀』の読みに従います。
sen.e: When Emperor Tenmu who had died in the previous year was buried in Ochi-no-misasagi Tomb on December 11, 688, OTOMO no Sukune Miyuki and FUSE no Minushi (AHE no Minushi) delivered eulogies.
sen.cmt: 「持統天皇2年11月11日」をグレゴリオ暦に変更しました。「誄した」をdelivered eulogiesとしました。

sen.j: 天武天皇の代に御行の地位は官人の中では中級にとどまっていたが、持統天皇の代には、高市皇子、多治比島に次ぎ、布勢御主人（阿倍御主人）と並ぶ高い地位に上った。
sen.e: In the period of Emperor Tenmu, Miyuki had been at the middle rank, however, in the period of Empress Jito, he was raised to a higher rank which was equal to the rank of FUSE no Minushi (ABE no Minushi) and the next highest to the rank of Takechi no Miko (Prince Takechi) and of TAJIHI no Shima.

Although Miyuki had been at the middle rank in the period of Emperor Tenmu, he was ranked as high as FUSE no Minushi (AHE no Minushi) following Takechi no Miko (Prince Takechi) and of TAJIHI no Shima in the period of Empress Jito.
sen.cmt: 布勢御主人（阿倍御主人）FUSE no Minushi (AHE no Minushi)…岩波文庫『日本書紀』の読みに従います。全体的に簡略化しました。

sen.j: 持統天皇5年（691年）1月13日に、布勢御主人とともに80の封戸を増し与えられ、前のとあわせて300戸になった。
sen.e: On January 13, 691 (in old lunar calendar), Miyuki and FUSE no Minushi were given the additional salary, 80 fuko (equal to 80 taxed families); at the result their salary was increased to 300 fuko (300 taxed families).

sen.e: On January 2, 694 (in old lunar calendar), Miyuki and FUSE no Minushi were raised to Shokoshi (junior third rank), and given 200 fuko (equal to 200 taxed families) as the additional salary; at the result, their salary was increased to 500 fuko (500 taxed families); besides, each of them became Ujinokonokami (head of clan).

sen.e: At this occasion, by reports of Junsatsushi (Megurimiru-tsukai or circuit inspector), several Kokushi (Kuni-no-mikotomochi or governor of province) such as Inaba-no-kuni no Kami (governor of Inaba Province) FUNE no Hatakatsu and Tomi-no-kuni no Kami (governor of Tomi Province) NURIBE no Michimaro were raised to higher ranks, therefore Miyuki and Minushi are considered to have been Kokushi, however, which provinces they served are unknown.
